completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 14­361, Ocasio v. United States. Mr. Davis.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: The Hobbs Act requires that a defendant obtain property from another. In this case, Mr. Ocasio was charged with conspiring with the owners of a repair shop not to obtain property from another, but from the owners themselves. The plain language of the Hobbs Act resolves this case. When two people agree that one will pay the other a bribe, they have merely agreed to exchange property between themselves, not to obtain property from another. The historical background, the statutory structure, and basic criminal ­­ principles of criminal law all point in the same direction. There are no old English or State cases involving conspiracies to extort property from a co­conspirator.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Does that mean that you would have to ­­ in order to get at this ­­ this venture, you would have to bring two separate prosecutions, one against your client for the extortion, and then a separate crime ­­ a separate prosecution in State court against the body shop owners?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Yes, Justice Ginsburg, I think that is correct. Maryland has a bribery statute that might apply in a situation like this. And Congress has passed a bribery statute targeted to bribery of State and local officials, 18 U.S.C. 666, that may or may not apply to the repair shop owners. But we don't think they could be convicted of ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Is it ­­ is it well established, or even not well established, that you are obtaining property under color of law when you give somebody a bribe?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Your Honor ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: It seems to me ­­ what that means to me under color of law is you ­­ you pretend to have a legal right to it, which in fact you don't have.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Justice Scalia, until 1992, I think that was an open question, but this Court decided in Evans v. United States in '92 that Hobbs Act extortion encompasses the paying of ­­ of bribes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: I dissented, I assume.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: You did. But, Your Honor, I think that that ­­ the decision in Evans was really the high­water mark of this Court's Hobbs Act jurisprudence. And since then the Court has been careful not to expand the Hobbs Act ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Well, we have stated that a person may be liable for conspiracy even though he was incapable of committing the substantive offense. Does that carry the day for the government's argument here, or is that distinguishable at principle?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: I think that's distinguishable in principle, Justice Kennedy.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: And why?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Well, certainly not every conspirator must personally commit every element of the substantive offense.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: But he might not even be capable of it, must not even be capable of it, as I understand what we've said.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: That's correct, Your Honor. Must ­­ need not even be capable of committing every element of the substantive offense, but each conspirator must specifically intend that someone commit every element of the substantive offense. And ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: Well, why isn't that test satisfied here, because the shop owners agreed that Mr. Ocasio would commit every element of the substantive offense?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: The shop owners, Your Honor, agree that Mr. Ocasio would obtain property from another, not from themselves. So I think that ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: Well, the ­­ the ­­ Mr. Ocasio is committing every element of the substantive offense. He is obtaining property from another; that is, he's obtaining property from the body shop owners. And the body shop owners agreed that he would do so. So it seems to me that in the normal way that conspiracy law works, there is a conspiracy here.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Justice Kagan, I don't think that's quite right. I think that there must be a unity of purpose in conspiracy law. And the ­­ Mr. Ocasio may have agreed to obtain property from another, but the body shop owners agreed to obtain property from themselves; so there's no unity of purpose.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: They only need to agree that he should obtain property from another, and that is exactly what they agreed to.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Justice Kagan, I think the best way to approach your question is through imagining how this would happen in ordinary English. The government has a John and Susan ­­ has its response to our John and Susan hypothetical in its brief. It says, John would go to Susan and say, let us agree that I will obtain property from another, namely, you. And you notice how much work the words "namely you" are doing in the government's hypothetical. They're redefining the word "another" to mean the opposite of its ordinary meaning, not ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: Is that any stranger than the Mann Act situation, where the woman who is being transported across State lines for immoral purposes, conspires with the person who is transporting her across State lines? That's permissible, isn't it?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Justice Alito, I think yes, it is. And two distinctions from the Mann Act cases: The first is that the Mann Act used the phrase "any woman," not "another woman." I think that case would have been different if it had used the phrase "another woman."

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: Well, "any woman" is broader than "another woman." "Any woman" means any of 3.5 billion­plus women in the world, and that subsumes "another woman," doesn't it?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: I don't think so, Your Honor. I mean, I think that if a woman agreed to transport any woman, it makes sense to think that she could transport herself across State lines, but if the statute had said "another woman," it doesn't make sense to say that she could have transported another woman when she was merely transporting herself.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: Well, they're two different words, but the syntactical problem seems to me to be identical, which is that it's just not natural to say that the transported woman is herself transporting any woman, right? I mean, the transported woman is not transporting any woman. But the reason the Court said that a conspiracy was possible there was because the transported woman could agree with another person, let's say, the man, that the man would transport any woman, namely, herself. It's ­­ it's an almost identical syntactical issue.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: I don't think so, Your Honor. I think that transporting another woman would create a much bigger textual issue than transporting any woman. If the woman goes to the man who is transporting her and says, I'd like to help you transport another woman, he would think that she is talking about someone else, not about herself. It's much more natural in the context of "any woman." The other reason those cases are distinguishable, Your Honor, is because they use the verb "transport" instead of "obtain." It's ­­ it's conceivable to transport yourself; it's not really ­­ it doesn't really make sense to obtain property from yourself. So I think those are distinguishable on those grounds.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: What difference did it make in this ­­ you're ­­ you're not contesting the extortion convictions, right? You ­­ it's only the conspiracy; is that right?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: That's correct, Your Honor, with an asterisk, and that is if we were to prevail here, we would go back to the Fourth Circuit and ask to vacate the substantive convictions also on the basis of spillover prejudice. But for purposes of this appeal, you're correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: And did the addition of the conspiracy conviction affect the sentence? Would it have been different if there had been no conspiracy charge.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Your Honor, the sentences ran concurrently. The difference it made was $600 in restitution payments that were attributable to two acts of extortion that were not charged as substantive counts in the indictment.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: I have a small question, but not unimportant, which is: Who paid the bribe, Majestic or the brothers?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: The brothers paid the bribes, Your Honor, out of ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: Out of their own pockets, or did they ­­

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Out of the ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: ­­ Majestic, issue a check?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Out of the Majestic bank account, Your Honor.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: So why isn't Majestic the other person here?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Your Honor, the government forfeited any argument that Majestic is the "another" by not raising it at any ­­ at any stage in this Court, in ­­ either in its cert stage briefing or in the ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Was Majestic a separate corporation or was it just the proprietorship­owned?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: The record is a little unclear on that point. The testimony, to the extent it shows anything, shows that Majestic was an LLC and then it became a corporation at some point later. It's not clear when. But I think the government didn't raise that argument for a good reason, and that's because the testimony also showed that Moreno and Mejia were the sole owners of Majestic, and that there was no difference between them in practical effect. So in ­­ in practice, the money really came from the ­­ from Moreno and Mejia, not from ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: Well, Moreno and Mejia are two ­­ are two people; they're not the same person, right? So I assume even if it was ­­ let's say it was a partnership, they each would be entitled to half of the money, right?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: I think that's ­­ that's correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: So Moreno could conspire with Ocasio to obtain money from Mejia and Mejia could conspire with Ocasio to obtain money from Moreno.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Your Honor, I don't think that that theory works in this case because the bribes came from them jointly. The payments came from them together. They ­­ they were both aware of what each other were doing and I think that they're indistinguishable for purposes of this.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Did this government argue this proposition as its theory of the case in the trial court or here?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: No, not that theory of the case, Your Honor.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: You ­­ you acknowledge that the ­­ that the police officer is ­­ is guilty of a violation of the Hobbs Act, never mind the conspiracy, but just the Hobbs Act violation.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: We're not directly challenging that here, Your Honor.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Well, if you don't ­­ if you don't challenge that here, I ­­ as I recall, your briefs say that to disagree with you in this case is to establish a Federal law of bribery for the whole country. But it seems to me you ­­ you have that once you ­­ once you acknowledge that, never mind the conspiracy charge, but just the substantive Hobbs Act charge. That's a national bribery law, isn't it?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Justice Scalia, on one side of the transaction, yes, on the public official side of the transaction. But this Court in Evans did not ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Well, that's all you need to have a national law against bribery, it seems to me. You just get one of the two, I don't think you have to get both.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Well, Your Honor, if ­­ if this Court were to extend Evans in this case to cover not only the public official side of the transaction but also the private citizen side of the transaction, that would be a dramatic expansion of the law of bribery. I mean, Evans may or may not have been ­­ have been correct, but I think it was the high­water mark, and the Court has been careful not to ­­ not to extend it even further in the years since.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: What about ­­ what do you do with the government's argument that Ocasio was conspiring with other police officers to get the money from another? In other words, that conspiracy got money from another, the ­­ the two individuals.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Two responses to that, Your Honor. The first is that under the jury instructions, the jury could have convicted Ocasio based on a conspiracy solely between him and the repair shop owners, and under this Court's decision in Skilling, if a ­­ if the jury could have returned a legally­invalid verdict, the conviction has to be reversed. And I think that's a sufficient answer to the question, but my second answer is that we disagree with the government that there was sufficient evidence in the record linking Ocasio with other police officers. The evidence showed only that these police officers were generally aware of what each other were doing. It didn't show that they formed an agreement to work together. And under this Court's decision in Kotteakos, it was a hub­and­spokes conspiracy without the rim enclosing the spokes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: I think if I'm remembering the government's response to your first point, is that it certainly would have been harmless error in this case.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Your Honor, I find that response a little difficult to understand. The ­­ the trial overwhelmingly focused on linking Ocasio with Moreno and Mejia, not with other police officers. The vast majority of the testimony was about Moreno and Mejia forming an agreement with Ocasio. The government's whole case went through Moreno and Mejia. And the government would have had a much more difficult case if it had to prove an agreement between police officers to obtain property from Moreno and Mejia. There just wasn't that much evidence of such an agreement. Everything, again, went through that, hub of Moreno and Mejia. So it's hard for me to imagine that it would have been harmless error, let alone that the jury would even have convicted if it had been instructed that it had to find an agreement between multiple police officers.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: Is there any difference to your argument based on the government's position that your client was charged under the general conspiracy statute and not the Hobbs Act statute?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Justice Sotomayor, no, I don't think it makes a difference. The general conspiracy statute just leads ­­ just leads the government straight back to the Hobbs Act. It punishes each person who conspires to commit an offense against the United States. The offense gets against the United States here is Hobbs Act extortion. One of its elements is obtaining the property from another, so I think the general conspiracy statute it leads right back to the Hobbs Act in just maybe an extra step.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: That's my problem, which is it's not an extra step. You can conspire, if not every ­­ you started by saying that not every conspirator has to be ­­ commit the ­­ of every element of the crime. So why can't the general conspiracy statute do the work?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Well, under the general conspiracy statute, just like under the Hobbs Act, Your Honor, every conspirator has to specifically intend that someone commit every element of the crime. I think that's been ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: Well, is that ­­ that begs Justice Kagan's question, which is they wanted Ocasio ­­ they wanted the police officer to act under color of right and to take the bribe.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: And I think the key problem with that, Your Honor, is that the repair shop owners did not intend to help Ocasio obtain property from another. They intended to help Ocasio obtain property from themselves. And I think that's why there's not a unity of purpose here. I mean, all ­­ everyone may have agreed on the same course of conduct, like the government says. And I think the only way the government can make its interpretation sound plausible is by obscuring the words "from another."

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: No, I don't think that's right. The "from another" is clearly an element of the substantive offense. But you're saying it should also be a freestanding limit on the conspiracy offense, and there's no reason for that to be true. It is, of course, right that somebody has to obtain property from another, but the conspiracy offense is made out if two people agree that somebody should obtain property from another. And that's exactly the situation here.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Your Honor, I think that, again, the repair shop owners did not intend to obtain property from another. And ­­ and I think the way that ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: They intended and they agreed that Mr. Ocasio should obtain property from another. And that's all they have to do.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Your Honor, I think going back to how that kind of conversation would happen in ordinary English is a way to see why it's not plausible to read the statute like that. If the repair shop owners go to Ocasio and say, I want to help you obtain property from another, Ocasio would think that they're talking about someone else. I think the government's interpretation is much more formalistic.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: It's a statute, and the statute just says the other has to be somebody different from Ocasio himself. So in this particular case, the somebody other is the people who are in the agreement. In another case, the somebody other might be somebody who is outside the agreement. The statute just ­­ the ­­ the substantive law says it has to be from another. The conspiracy ­­ and this is just ­­ it's consistent with Salinas, it's consistent with Holt, it's consistent with everything we've ever said about conspiracy law ­­ is that it just has to be an agreement for somebody to do that substantive offense even if the people agree and can't do it themselves. And it's true, the people agreeing can't do it themselves. They can't obtain property from another. But Mr. Ocasio can, and they're agreeing that he should.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Your Honor, even if that's a plausible interpretation of the statute, which we don't think it is, it's definitely not the most natural way to read it. If you talk to any ­­ any nonlawyer about the statute, they would ­­ they would say that if you agree to form ­­ if you agree to obtain property from another, you'd be talking about someone outside the conspiracy. And, you know, the government's interpretation also requires you to figure out how someone can conspire to obtain their own consent. It requires shifting perspectives as you navigate your way through the statute. And I think that our interpretation is ­­ is much more consistent with the way people would actually talk about this offense. I mean, in some form ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: What about aiding and abetting? Could the brothers who own the body shop, could they ­­ could they be charged with aiding and abetting ­­

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Justice Ginsburg ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: ­­ the extortion?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Justice Ginsburg, I don't think that they could. I think the same textual problem would exist for aiding and abetting liability. 18 U.S.C. 2 is the general aiding and abetting statute, and it leads you straight back to the Hobbs Act in the same way that the general conspiracy statute does. So I don't ­­ I don't think so.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Is it ­­ is it extortion or attempted extortion? If two brothers, as here, try to get money from a third party and the third party really wants to give them the money ­­ say, for example, he wants to give them the money because he's going to illustrate how awful the police are in that town. Or he gives them the money because he thinks it's funny. Or he gives them the money ­­ is that extortion? Because I'm having trouble distinguishing between why it should be extortion but not conspiracy for extortion, because that's what you're aiming at. You're prepared to say, okay, it's extortion. Well, if it's extortion, you've heard all the arguments and why can't these other people commit it and you're simply helping them. But is it extortion?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Your Honor, this Court has defined extortion in Evans to mean ­­ to basically mean when a public official takes a bribe, and, you know, we take that holding as a given.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: He takes a bribe, all right? Is it ­­ is it a bribe when the person just showers him with money, hoping for nothing illegal?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: No.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: He might think it's a bribe, but ­­ but is it?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Well, Your Honor, there has ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: He voluntarily gives him the money expecting joy and happiness. I mean, you see, that's where it seems to me the odd part of the case lies.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Well, Your Honor, I think if he just gave him ­­ showered him with gifts not expecting anything, it would not be extortion because there has to be a quid pro quo. The money has to be paid in return for specific official acts. So that would not be an act of ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: All right. So if bribe, then we're back ­­ if bribery is extortion, then why isn't conspiracy to commit bribery conspiracy to commit extortion? We're back where we began. The odd thing is in calling bribery extortion. Once you cross that bridge ­­ that's where we started. But we're back ­­ in my mind, it sort of got back where we started. And you're trying to drive a wedge there, and all your arguments seem to be me, really, to be aimed at why are we calling bribery extortion?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: I don't ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Because they are showering with money. They love it.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Your Honor, we're not taking direct aim at Evans. And I don't ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: I know that, but, I mean, how you're asking me to make that distinction, how do I do it?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Well, Your Honor, I think Evans dealt with a substantive offense, and this case deals with conspiracy. And when you overlay a conspiratorial agreement on top of a substantive offense, it just stops making sense grammatically to talk about the offense the way the government does. Again, when two people reach an agreement that one will pay the other one a bribe, it just ­­ it doesn't make sense of ordinary English to say that they're agreeing to obtain property from someone else, from another. I also think ­­ you know, I don't want the phrase "with his consent" to get lost here also. The Hobbs Act punishes the obtaining of property with his ­­ from another with his consent. And as Judge Sutton explained in ­­ in the Brock decision, how can someone conspire ­­ how would or why ­­ how could or why would someone conspire to obtain their own consent? So even if you don't agree with us on the ­­ on the "from another" language, I think the "with his consent" language does it as well. And then the other textual point ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, before ­­ I mean, the government says, of course, is there's ­­ there's consent and there's consent, and they suggest that there's a difference between consent and conspiracy. Right?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, what's your answer to that?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Well, we agree with that, Your Honor. We think that there are plenty of instances of consent under the Hobbs Act that would not be a conspiratorial agreement. But it's hard to see what payment of a bribe would not be a conspiratorial agreement under the government's theory. Maybe there's some narrow category of cases where the bribe pair is just acquiescing to an official demand as it ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: And what payment of a bribe is not extortion?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: I ­­ I agree, Your Honor. I think ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: All right. So the only ground, then, we could say is say, well, they went just up to the limit of the logic in the other case, and we're just not going to be logical to extend it further.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: I think ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Is that ­­

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: I don't think that's quite right, Your Honor.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Works for me.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: I ­­ I think that is a ground, Your Honor. I don't think it's the only ground. I think the other ground would be the plain text of the statute. I mean, Evans ­­ in Evans, the ­­ the government didn't have the same textual problem that it has in this case. The government didn't have to grapple with the "from another" language. And in this case, "from another" most naturally means someone outside the ­­ the conspiracy. The other point ­­ textual point I'd like to ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: Mr. Davis, if you could go back to what you just said about the consent. I mean, look, I mean, Evans makes perfectly clear that bribes and kickbacks are included in this statute. And ­­ and there is a difference between ­­ there ­­ there are cases in which somebody participates in a kickback scheme and does not consent. I mean, suppose some public official comes in and says, in order for me to give you a license to do something, to be, you know, a member of some profession, let's say a cosmetologist, you need to pay me $20 as a kickback. And the person, you know, pays him $20 because you've got to get your license. But there's no way in the world in which that would count as a conspiratorial agreement. It would count as consent under the Hobbs Act. So there's a big gap between consent and a conspiratorial agreement, even in the context of bribes.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Justice Kagan, I don't disagree with you, but with an asterisk. I think there is a gray area there where someone just acquiesces to an official demand like you're saying. Those may not be conspiratorial agreements. But I think still, there is a large category of bribery cases that would ­­ would still be conspiratorial agreements under the government's theory, anytime someone, like in Salinas, pays a bribe in exchange for official action and wasn't required to do so. So I think still the government's theory would render some of the language in 666 unnecessary. You know, 18 U.S.C. 666 has specific monetary thresholds put on when a bribe is a Federal crime. And the ­­ and none of ­­ the bribe has to be over $5,000. The State official has to work for an agency that receives $10,000 or more in Federal funds. And I think in a lot of those cases, the government could just avoid those limitations by charging the case as a conspiracy to commit extortion under the Hobbs Act. And that's even though there may be a category of cases that would not be a conspiratorial agreement, but that would be consent under the Hobbs Act. On one more textual point, Your Honors, the statute also punishes whoever conspires to obtain property from another, which, I think, reinforces our reading that the "whoever" who obtains the property has to be a different person from the "another" from whom property is obtained. And I think the general conspiracy statute gets to the same place by just a slightly more circuitous route. It punishes each person who conspires to commit any offense against the United States.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: Is it fair to say that you are advancing an argument that is limited to the precise language of the Hobbs Act? You ­­ you are not taking issue with the proposition that a person can conspire to commit offense that the person could not personally commit. And you distinguish the Hobbs Act from the Mann Act because one refers to "any" and another refers to "another." So is it fair to say that what you want is a special conspiracy rule that applies only in cases of Hobbs Act conspiracies?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: No, Your Honor. I think that what we're asking for is just to apply the language of the general conspiracy statute in light of the words from another in the Hobbs Act. And when you put the two together ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: And if another substantive offense doesn't have the word "obtain property from" ­­ the phrase "obtain property from another," then your ­­ your rule doesn't apply?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: I think that's generally right, Your Honor. Our textual arguments would not apply. I think there would still be an issue of, you know, there's a ­­ there's a principle that when the substantive offense requires the ­­ necessarily requires agreement, you're not supposed to add a conspiracy charge on that, but that's just a presumption. I think you're right that our ­­ our textual argument would not ­­ would not apply in the absence of the words "another," "with his consent," and "whoever." I'd like ­­ if there are no further questions, I'd like to reserve my time for rebuttal.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Kedem.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: A conspiracy is an agreement to commit an offense against the United States, that is, a joint commitment to a plan that, if completed, would satisfy all elements of the substantive offense. And while all conspirators must agree on that goal, no particular member of the conspiracy must agree that he, himself, will commit all or even any of the substantive elements of the offense. And so you don't ask whether all conspirators or the conspiracy as a whole agreed to obtain property from another any more than you would ask whether the conspiracy as a whole acted under color of official right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Do ­­ do you agree that under your approach, every private individual who seeks to bribe a State official is liable for conspiracy to commit Hobbs Act extortion?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: We don't. And that's because of active participation. Let me explain where that comes from and then how it applies to this case. Holte and Gebardi concerned the Mann Act, which prohibited the transportation of a woman across State lines for immoral purposes. And the question was whether a woman who was transported could conspire to violate the Act. In answering that question, the Court focused on two things. First of all, although the Act contemplates the involvement of the woman, it doesn't impose substantive criminal liability on her. And, second, some minimal form of agreement is an inherent feature of most instances of the offense. Based on those two factors, the Court said, if that's all there is, if the only thing that the woman agrees to is to the transportation itself, that is, the bare outlines of the crime, that by itself would be insufficient to make her a conspirator. But if she were to agree to do more ­­ if, for instance, she were to purchase the tickets or to arrange the transportation in some other way ­­ then she could be a conspirator. And so in this case, with respect to a bribe pair, if all the bribe pair agrees to do is turn over money in return for official acts, that by itself would be insufficient to make the bribe pair a conspirator.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Well, suppose he arranges to meet on the park bench at 2:00 o'clock, and has a follow­up call to the official to please be there. Is that ­­ does that suffice?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I think that would be incidental to the one thing that they're really agreeing to do, which is to turn over the money. But contrast that with what happened in this case. Because Moreno and Mejia didn't just hand over an envelope with $100 bills in it. They worked closely in conjunction with police officers, including Petitioner. For instance, when Petitioner went to the scene of an accident, he would call Moreno, and they would talk about what cars were involved: The make, model, the year, what extent of damage was involved. And then Moreno would consult with Petitioner about which cars would be most lucrative to have in the shop. And so it wasn't simply a case of agreeing to the bare outlines of the crime. He agreed to facilitate it in additional ways.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: How do you charge that to a jury?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Pardon?

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: How do you charge it to a jury?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I think you would tell the jury two things. First, in order for a bribe pair to be a conspirator, they have to agree to actively participate in the plan. And second ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: Well, I mean, I'm a juror and I say, I ­­ police officer came to me, asked me for 20 bucks, and he'll let me go for my ticket. I'm active participation. That's what I'm thinking.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: The second one is that you would have to tell the jury that if all you've agreed to do is to turn over money in return for official acts, then that by itself is insufficient.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Okay. That's lovely. And that ­­ you know, that prevents this law from ­­ Federal law from hitting anybody who pays a bribe, which is certainly a desirable result. But I don't see how it comports with your theory of the case. I mean, there is just as much of an agreement between the two people to obtain money from another, whether that other actively participates or not. Where ­­ where do you get this active participation requirement from?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Well ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Except to make it up to sweeten the deal, so that ­­ so that we ­­ we don't extend this ­­ this law too far.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Active participation comes from Holte and Gebardi, and it's also notable that the government didn't make up the requirement for purposes of this case. The First, Second, Fourth, and Fifth Circuits have used active participation in the context of Hobbs Act extortion ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: And where did they get it from?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: They get it from ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: And where did Holte and Gebardi get it from?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I think Holte and Gebardi see it as a gloss on the type of agreement that's necessary to make a particular person a conspirator.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: But that's not what conspiracy law says. It's any agreement. If ­­ if you agree, you're ­­ you're liable to conspiracy. Where ­­ where do ­­ can ­­ can you hang on this active ­­ is there an active participation requirement for other conspiracies?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: In this ­­ in this Court's case in Abuelhawa, which is cited at footnote 8 in our brief, the Court also relied on Gebardi to raise the level of facilitation that would be required for a drug purchaser to be held liable for facilitating the sale of a drug.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: But I ­­ I ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Where is the ­­ the active participation point in the jury instructions?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: It's not in the jury instructions because Petitioner never requested it, despite the fact that active participation was already the law in the Fourth Circuit. I would also point out that it was Petitioner's argument that it simply doesn't matter how actively a bribe pair facilitates the extortion. Moreover, there was no dispute in this case that Moreno and Mejia made an active role. In fact, it was Petitioner's contention at trial that they were, in fact, the masterminds of this scheme. Justice Scalia, if you don't like active participation, then you would simply revert to the common law standard in which agreeing to the outlines of the crime would be sufficient, even if you were a bribe pair.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: So if ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: That makes sense to me.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: If ­­ if I could just understand what you're saying, you think active participation is more than an agreement along the typical conspiracy lines.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I think normally agreeing to the bare outlines of the crime would be sufficient for most conspirators. I think ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Would ­­ would?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Would, that's correct. But I think active participation is a way to raise the threshold ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: Right. But ­­

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: ­­ certain types of crimes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: ­­ this does sound more like an aiding and abetting standard than it does a conspiracy standard, because typically in conspiracy we say it doesn't really matter if you actively participate, as long as you reach an agreement.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: Now that agreement is more than acquiescence, right? It's more than I reluctantly give you the bribe that you're demanding of me.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: That's right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: But ­­ but I guess I'm with Justice Scalia that I don't really quite understand how to get from the typical real agreement that we require in conspiracy cases to some higher standard with respect to this crime of active participation.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I think it's a gloss on what you have to agree to do in order to be considered a conspirator. So it's true that the agreement itself is what's criminal when it comes to a conspiracy, whereas with aiding and abetting, it's acts. And I think it's a similar inquiry. With aiding and abetting, you act ­­ you ask: Did you actively participate in the crime? And with conspiracy, you ask: Did you agree to actively participate in the crime? If I could attack ­­ if I could refer to my friend's argument about unity of purpose, he's correct that there does need to be a unity of purpose, but he's incorrect as to what that purpose needs to be. Under Salinas, all members of the conspiracy must agree on a plan that is an offense against the United States; that is, an offense, a plan that, if completed, would satisfy all elements of the substantive offense. And Petitioner says Evans was the high­water mark in interpreting the Hobbs Act. But the ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: The ­­ the answer, as I understand this now, the purpose of this active participation doctrine is let's look at the substantive offense. And all of a sudden we're saying every policeman, every State official, everyone in the country who goes to any person and says, give me some money for my position, they're already guilty. That already is extortion on this case that we've been talking about before, right?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: That's right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Okay.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: But ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: So now what you're going to do is you're going to make not only them guilty of the Federal crime, you're going to make anybody who pays them guilty of the Federal crime. That's the purpose of this case. Now you say don't worry about it, because there's situation A and situation B. In situation A, the policeman is the heavy, and all the victim's done is stop at the traffic light. He says, give me the money, and that's a bribe, all right? He's a bad guy, the policeman; the victim is not so bad. But in the other case, the victim says, I love it, like these people, because we're really getting money from the public. That's what they're trying to do ­­ who are the real victims here, but they're not ­­ that's not charged that way. And that's what the active participation thing is designed to do, separate the ­­ the sort of innocent victims who aren't policemen from the cooperating victims who love the policemen to take the money because they want the result; is that right?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I think that's correct. I think ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Okay. I've got it right so far.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: That's ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: The argument on his side is don't make a bad situation worse.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Well ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: We already are federalizing vast numbers of State crimes, which really are the States' business. And now you're not necessarily doubling the number, but you're increasing it by about 80 percent. Now that ­­ that's what I've got as a practical argument that he's making. And ­­ and your answer to that is, don't worry it's not your business. It's just follow the logic.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I think under active participation, you wouldn't be doing that.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: I understand.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I would also point ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: What I'm interested in is if I understand it correctly.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I think you do, Your Honor. I would also point out that the argument he makes with regard to "from another" has nothing in particular to do with the Hobbs Act. It would apply any time a statute uses phrases like "from another" or "to another." And let me give you an example.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, before you do, I'm still stuck on the jury instructions. You cite in your brief language on Joint Appendix page 195 where the judge says ­­ I think these are the instructions. Maybe I'm wrong, but you cite them, where the judge says mere knowledge or acquiescence without participation in the unlawful plan is not sufficient. Is that ­­ that's the language, I take it, you're talking about with ­­

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: That's ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: ­­ "the jury was instructed."

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: That was given ­­ given the jury, but I think that's the standard conspiracy instruction.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, on page 194, it says, "The extent of a defendant's participation has no bearing on the issue of his guilt." And I just wondered whether your ­­ it's active participation. That suggests to me something that goes to the extent of the defendant's participation.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: That's right. A different instruction would be given, but it's important to emphasize that Petitioner did not appeal the failure to give a specific jury instruction. He didn't request one, and that was not the basis for appeal. He had a sufficiency of the evidence challenge on appeal, and that's what's before this Court. Moreover, there is overwhelming evidence that Moreno and Mejia did, in fact, actively participate. In fact, that was Petitioner's very theory at trial. But let me give you an example of how Petitioner's argument with regard to "from another" does not necessarily only focus on the Hobbs Act. Imagine the for instance, there was a statute that said if you steal from a bank while pointing a gun at another, it's aggravated bank robbery. And imagine a robber says to his friend, you go into the bank ahead of me. I'll run in, point a gun at your head, and say, cashier give me all of your money. According to Petitioner, that would not be conspiracy, because judged ­­ from the perspective of the conspiracy as a whole, no gun was pointed at another. And at base, Petitioner's argument is that every element of the substantive offense has to be judged in a conspiracy from the perspective of the conspiracy as a single, undifferentiated whole. A couple responses to that. First of all, it's not even clear what that means; for instance, how it could be that a conspiracy as a whole obtains property under color of official right. Second of all, it contradicts the very premise behind conspiracy liability, which is that different members of the conspiracy agree to play different roles, and it's only when you add those various roles together that you get the completed offense.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: I'm afraid you haven't scared me. I don't ­­ I don't think that in the situation you posit where ­­ where the ­­ the two gunmen say you come into the bank with me and I'll point the gun at your head and say, what, unless you cough up the money, I'm going to shoot my friend. I don't see why that would be a conspiracy ­­

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I don't ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: ­­ to point a gun at another.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I don't think, Justice Scalia, you would say, give me the money or I'll kill my friend. I think the friend would pretend to be a customer in the bank.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Sure. But ­­ well ­­

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: And I think the two of them would have formed the plan in order to accomplish the aggravated robbery.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: And I would not think that that's a conspiracy to point a gun at another.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Well, Justice ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: It's a conspiracy to point a gun between themselves.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Justice Scalia, I think that only is true if you judge each element of the offense ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: No, I understand ­­

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: ­­ with regard to the conspiracy.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: ­­ but you were trying to present a clear example.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Sure.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: And it doesn't seem to me very clear at all.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Justice Scalia, we cite about a half dozen other Federal statutes that also similarly use phrases like "from another" and "to another" that would be similarly affected by Petitioner's argument. I would also like to ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: But the other reason your hypothetical doesn't work too well is we know that he's not going to pull the gun because he's his friend, but in this case the money is going to be given. So it doesn't work.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Well, Justice Kennedy, I would point you then to the statute that we cite that talks about someone who is a government official who receives coded, secret information from another and provides it to another. Petitioner's only response is there may be some other statute that you could prosecute under in the case in which the "from another" and "to another" are both officials of other governments. But what if there are not? What if they're officials ­­ what if they're members of a terrorist organization, for instance? I'd like to also address my friend's argument with respect to the word "whoever" in Subsection A. I don't think it works for a couple reasons. First of all, the word "whoever" in Subsection A ­­ and this is best addressed if looking directly at the words of the statute at page 2a to the appendix to our brief. "Whoever," in Subsection (a), is not the subject of the phrase "obtaining of property from another" in Subsection (b)(2). If it were, then no private citizen could ever be member of a conspiracy because no private citizen can obtain property from another under color of official right. Instead, the word "whoever" is the subject of the phrase "obstructs, delays, or affects commerce" by extortion or agrees or conspires so to do. And to give you an example of how that can be affected, even if you yourself are not the person who commits the extortion, imagine a case of robbery in which there is a central organizer who brings together robbers who have various skills and gives them a plan but doesn't himself intend to participate in the robbery. In that case, he would have conspired to obstruct, delay, or affect commerce by robbery, even though he himself would not be committing robbery. And the same is true with respect to extortion. Moreno and Mejia were part of a plan which they actively facilitated that obstructed, delayed, and affected commerce by extortion.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Well, is it ­­ if ­­ what ­­ I'm still ­­ a crime requires that the victim give consent. Now, what kind of ­­ it could be obtaining consent to do something. Smith obtains consent to do something. The victim agrees with Smith to participate in that crime. But in agreeing to do it, he is giving consent. So from that point on, there is no further consent to be given. So it's like robbing the pocket of a stone idol or some ­­ what used to be called in law school ­­ once the consent is given. So maybe he is agreeing to participate in a conspiracy to attempt to get the consent. But he's agreeing to the ­­ he gives the consent at the moment he agrees.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Justice Breyer ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: So how can you be conspiring to ­­ to do something to get a consent that was already given?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Justice Breyer ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: You could conspire to attempt to get it, but not to get it, if you're being really picky on these words.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: The issue of consent is really a red herring in this case, because as my friend just stated, consent from the common law for extortion falls well below the meeting of the minds that you would need for conspiratorial agreement. And that much is made clear by the fact that even in cases of coercive extortion, that is extortion induced by wrongful use of actual or threatened force, violence, or fear, you would still need consent. And so the type of agreement that we're talking about, with or without the active participation requirement, is well above the threshold for consent under the common law.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: You haven't talked about Majestic yet, and your friend said that's maybe because you had never raised that below. Is that ­­ is that true? In other words, the Majestic is the other from which the funds are going to be obtained?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: That's not accurate. It was raised in the trial court. The trial court made a ruling that Majestic was also another, and the court of appeals decided not to adopt that argument. We haven't pursued it in this Court. I would also point out ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Was that just ­­ was that in your brief in opposition to certiorari?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: We talked about the fact that in this case you could look at Majestic as another, and we talked about that in the context of the Brock case out of the Sixth Circuit, but we're not ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Is Majestic a sole proprietorship?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: It started out as an LLC, but became a corporation, as cited in footnote 1 of our brief.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: Was it indicted as part of this crime?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: It wasn't indicted, but it was in the indictment stated that money came from Majestic.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: You do say in your brief that if we adopt the Petitioner's argument, that basically you would never have any cases. But I'm not sure that's right. For example, the most common situation is the New York City permitting official. Generally, they agree with developers to have contractors pay them a bribe to expedite their work. That, you could prosecute because two people are agreeing to get money from another, the contractors. Those situations are not so unusual.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I don't ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: I think, as one of my colleagues said, there was a conspiracy here to get money from the victims.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I don't think, Justice Sotomayor, that our argument is you would never have instances in which the conspiracy provision would apply. I think what we're saying is, this is precisely the type of scenario in which conspiracy liability should attach. And I think there may be a sense by some that clever prosecutors, maybe in some cases, are pushing the bounds of conspiracy law beyond where they're ­­ traditionally have gone, and using it in ways that perhaps are not warranted. Whatever the merits of that criticism as a general matter, this is not that case. The criminal conspiracy in this case was a durable, multifaceted, criminal enterprise that had a division of labor and succeeded over the course of several years in committing not only numerous acts of extortion, but other forms of illegality as well.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: You had no other substantive crime to charge against the brothers?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: The brothers also pled guilty to aiding and abetting extortion which, under Petitioner's theory, would not have been possible.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Why didn't you just charge them with getting money from the customers? I mean, that's who ­­ they're conspiring ­­ after all, they're giving $150 to the policeman. They aren't philanthropists. They think they're going to get that money back from the people whose cars are wrecked.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: That's correct. They could also ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: So those are the other people. I mean, this is really a conspiracy on behalf of the policeman and the ­­ and the owner of the repair shop to get money from a customer, a person whose car was wrecked. That's why they do it; isn't it?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: That is true, Justice Breyer, but they didn't necessarily commit a crime against the customer if all they did is repair the customer's car. Now, they did also commit various forms of insurance fraud, but put that to the side. In this scheme, if all they did was get money from a customer and fix the car as promised, then they would not have committed a crime necessarily against the customer.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: And, indeed, isn't it right that what Justice Breyer is saying was the very theory behind Evans, why this was extortion, is because the real crime was to the public at large, not to any particular customer. But yes, there was a crime to the ­­ the general public.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: That's correct. The victim in cases of extortion is not necessarily the person who pays the bribe, who might do so willingly and might do so in order to get something from the public official.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: And the Federal government's interest in this case, right, the reason is ­­ is, what?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Well, Justice Scalia ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: That automobiles are instruments of interstate commerce?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Justice Scalia, I think Evans settled that the mere receipt of a bribe in return for performing officials acts is, in fact, extortion. And I don't think that's at issue here.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Oh, oh, it doesn't have to be any ­­ any Federal constitutional authority, just ­­

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: There does have the to be constitutional authority.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Well, what is it? I mean, here, it is ­­ I assume that it's automobiles.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: That's ­­ well, Justice Scalia, it's affecting commerce and there was evidence at trial that, for instance, insurance payments came from out of State. And that was specifically used to ­­ to show the affecting commerce element. I would also point out that if you were simply to charge Petitioner with three isolated instances of extortion, of the substantive act of extortion, it would not reflect the full range of his misconduct because, again, he didn't simply receive money and then refer cars for it. He worked closely in conjunction with Moreno and Mejia.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: You ­­ you agree with your friend's point, though, that charging the conspiracy gives the prosecutor considerably broader range in the evidence that he wants to admit at trial?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I think that that does sometimes happen, but that's a general principle that has no specific relation to the argument that Petitioner is making in this case.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: What is the relationship between that argument and the question of whether there's a conspiracy between Ocasio and Moreno and Mejia? It might apply to the conspiracy between ­­ the alleged conspiracy between Ocasio and the other police officers because it ­­ although it could allow the ­­ make it easier to admit evidence of what the other police officers did.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: That's right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: But what ­­ it has no ­­ whether or not there was a conspiracy between Ocasio and Moreno and Mejia doesn't seem to me to have anything ­­ anything to do with what evidence would be admissible at trial.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: That's right, Justice Alito.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, I thought you told me that was wrong. I thought you told me you agreed with your friend that it gives broader scope to the range of evidence that could be admitted beyond charging simply the substantive offense.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: It does ­­ it does, Mr. Chief Justice, but that would still have been true even if Moreno and Mejia were not charged as co­conspirators because there was voluminous evidence ­­ and we cited in the last portion of our brief ­­ that Petitioner conspired with other police officers as well. For instance, he was recruited into the scheme by another police officer, probably Officer Rodriguez, who was indicted along with him.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Do you ­­ do you agree that the most that that gets you is a remand to address the Skilling question?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: We don't. We don't. Skilling was an issue about jury instructions. And, again, Petitioner's challenge in the court of appeals as it ­­ and as it comes to this Court is not about the jury instructions. I would point you instead to Griffin v. United States, 502 U.S. 46, which talks about sufficiency challenges, which is what this is. And if you look at that evidence, not only was Petitioner recruited by other officers, he himself tried to recruit other officers into this scene. For instance, trying to set up his own referral network. Moreover, there was evidence that he and Officer Rodriguez worked together on at least one occasion to bring a car into Majestic.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: And ­­ and is it a sufficiency ­­ I would have thought it's a statutory interpretation challenge and not simply a sufficiency of the evidence challenge.

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: Well, Mr. Chief Justice, I don't think there was a specific instruction to the jury one way or another about whether they either could or couldn't find it just based on Moreno and Mejia. And as a result, because there was a general verdict, you don't know specifically whether the jury relied on Moreno and Mejia alone or whether they also relied on other officers. And under that circumstance, I think Griffin says it's a ­­ just a general sufficiency challenge.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, on that I guess your ­­ your friend says that the whole thrust of the case you presented was based on the conspiracy between the two brothers and the officer rather than the spokes, I guess is the jargon, involving the different officers with Ocasio. Is that true?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: We don't think that's true. I would refer you to all of the evidence we cite in the last section of our brief. This was the way it was indicted. The indictment itself said that Petitioner conspired with other officers. It was also specifically cited in the closing argument to the jury, that they were able to find that he had conspired with other officers. And there was a great deal of evidence that he did so.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: Isn't that just harmless error, assuming we agree with your ­­ your ­­ with the Petitioner and say the other has to be somebody else?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: We don't think that it's harmless error, but I do take your point that it's an alternative grounds for holding for the government.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: So you think it's sufficiency?

completeLines.speaker: KEDEM
completeLines.speech: I do. I think that's what Griffin v. United States says. If there are no further questions.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Davis, you have four minutes remaining.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Thank you. I'll start with my friend's Griffin point. We directly challenged the jury instructions in our brief in this Court and the government did not raise any sort of argument that this was just a sufficiency case there, so I think that is water under the bridge. But ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: But did you challenge the instructions in the district court as well?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: We challenged the jury instructions in the district court, yes, Your Honor. There was an objection raised to the government's proposed instructions there. I'd like to turn to the active participant standard. We agree with Justice Scalia that the active participant standard doesn't come from anything in the statute or anything in basic principles of conspiracy law. Conspiracy just requires an agreement and sometimes an overt act, and this active participant standard doesn't map on well to that at all. The government ­­ the cases that the government cites that supposedly apply, Holte and Gebardi to ­­ to Hobbs Act prosecutions really dealt with aiding and abetting, not with conspiracy. And it's much easier to see how the active participant standard applies in the context of aiding and abetting, which requires acts beyond mere agreement. But in the context of conspiracy, the only court really to have applied the active participant standard to conspiracy in any, in any significant way was the Fourth Circuit in the Spitler decision.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Will you, in your answer, get to what I think is the main point; the main point being, look, two policemen and a shop owner. The policemen say, give us money and we'll help you out later. That's extortion. All right. If that's extortion, then why isn't it conspiracy when, three weeks before they meet and bit by bit say, we will do that very thing which is extortion ­­

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: I think ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: ­­ the shopkeeper is helping the policemen do what is the thing that counts as extortion and, therefore, he's conspired with them. That's their very simple argument. A simple answer is?

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: The simple answer is that's not consistent with how ­­ with ordinary English, Your Honor. When two people ­­ when the repair shop owners go to the public official and say, I'd like to help you obtain property from another ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Yes. The "other" ­­ "another" means another other than the two policemen.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Only if ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: That's ­­ that's what this other case says. And the law says that it's another ­­ another other than them.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: I think the only way the government can make that sound plausible is by adding words to the statute ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: No, no, no words. Another. Another. Joe and Bill are the policemen; Sam is the shopkeeper. In the substantive crime, the other, another, means not the two policemen; it means Sam. And Sam, two weeks earlier, helped and conspired with the two policemen to get money from another; namely, Sam.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: And ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Odd, but English.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Justice Breyer, I think the words "namely Sam" are doing all the work there. If you cut out the words "namely Sam," all of a sudden it doesn't make sense anymore. If he goes to the police officers and says, let me help you obtain property from another, you need to add words to the statute in order for that to make sense.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: Mr. Davis, I don't think you need to add words. What you need is to shift perspective. There is a difference here, but that's the difference, that the government is insisting that you look at it from the perspective of the person who, in this case, is doing the acts of obtaining property from another. And you are insisting that it be looked at from the perspective of the person who has agreed to help him do that. But there's no reason under standard conspiracy law that we would use the perspective of the agreer rather than the perspective of the perpetrator.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Justice Kagan, with respect, I don't agree with that. I think that under standard conspiracy law, you look at the perspective of both. You have to have a unity of purpose with each conspirator to do the same thing.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: There absolutely is a unity of purpose, that one person should do the crime.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: Your Honor ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Go ahead.

completeLines.speaker: DAVIS
completeLines.speech: With the unity of ­­ there may ­­ that obscures the words "from another" from the statute. There may be a unity of purpose that they all do something, but it begs the question about whether the something that they're doing violates every element of the offense.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
